text:
Is it possible to have online WGLMakie interactive figure on a Franklin website? (as opposed to offline)
Maybe hosted on Pluto or nextjournal (to have a Julia kernel), and then just a link on the website to open a page with the figure? Or do I need a server?
I am thinking this would help when there is too heavy state cached for an offline web figure...
(I hope my question makes sense, I am not sure)

elements.text:

text: the data & processing has to live somewhere

elements.text: the data & processing has to live somewhere

text: that's either on the server hosting the website or the browser that's displaying them

elements.text: that's either on the server hosting the website or the browser that's displaying them

text: note that Pluto is running only locally, it's not hosted somewhere else by default

elements.text: note that Pluto is running only locally, it's not hosted somewhere else by default

text:
I understand that the data & processing has to live somewhere for online, and I think it is possible with nextjournal but I am not sure... no idea about Pluto

It would be cool to have an example somewhere if it is doable!

elements.text:

text: For julia/Pluto to basically run directly on arbitrary websites, you'd have to run julia on webassembly - there was some talk about this a few years ago, but I don't know if anything ever come out of it

elements.text: For julia/Pluto to basically run directly on arbitrary websites, you'd have to run julia on webassembly - there was some talk about this a few years ago, but I don't know if anything ever come out of it

text:
<https://greimel.github.io/networks-course/notebooks/disease.html> It kind of works, but it takes a while before it becomes interactive (click run on binder in the top-right corner)

as I understand there are plans to support a custom package compiled sysimage so that it becomes instant.

text: (I haven’t actually run this on binder, but I’d estimate it takes 10-15 minutes now)

text:
Cool!
I mostly wanted to know if it will be possible, say in a couple of month. No rush for me.

elements.text:
Cool!

text: Keeping a kernel running in something like nextjournal would be pretty expensive compared to renting a server... It may look like it could work, but I'm pretty sure they'll disallow it once you let it run longer than a day :smile: Of course you could have the people that want to look at it start the notebook, but that would require an account and minutes of startup times (and then would be very similar to binder or something like that)

elements.text: Keeping a kernel running in something like nextjournal would be pretty expensive compared to renting a server... It may look like it could work, but I'm pretty sure they'll disallow it once you let it run longer than a day

Of course you could have the people that want to look at it start the notebook, but that would require an account and minutes of startup times (and then would be very similar to binder or something like that)

text:
I can definitely afford a server. I was wondering if it was necessary...
For me it is important that things are very user friendly, so I don't want users to have to open and start the notebook

elements.text:
I can definitely afford a server. I was wondering if it was necessary...
For me it is important that things are very user friendly, so I don't want users to have to open and start the notebook

text: Yeah, I guess that's the only way then... There will be no serious offer to have a julia process running non stop for free

elements.text: Yeah, I guess that's the only way then... There will be no serious offer to have a julia process running non stop for free

text: in that case, a server is probably the best idea

elements.text: in that case, a server is probably the best idea

text: adding on to that - having multiple users run the same code over and over could really cost a lot of ressources

elements.text: adding on to that - having multiple users run the same code over and over could really cost a lot of ressources

text: so having them pre-rendered with only some interaction is probably a better idea

elements.text: so having them pre-rendered with only some interaction is probably a better idea
